```lean4
import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have h₁ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
    have h₂ := hL.2
    have h₃ := hL.1
    have h₄ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
      fin_cases L <;> simp_all (config := {decide := true}) <;>
        try { contradiction } <;>
        try { aesop }
    exact h₄
  have h₂ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by
    intro h
    use ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i
    have h₃ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by rw [hS]
    simp_all [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top, Finset.sum_range_one, h₁]
    <;> norm_num
    <;>
    linarith
  have h₃ : (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
    have h₄ : putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4) := by
      simp_all [putnam_1973_a2_solution]
      <;>
      tauto
    exact h₄
  exact ⟨h₂, h₃⟩
```

import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/

(L : List ℝ)

(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=

```lean4
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have h₁ : L.length = 8 := hL.1
  have h₂ : ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1 := hL.2
  have h₃ : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard := hpluses
  have h₄ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i := hS
  have h₅ : ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1 := by simpa using h₂
  have h₆ : L.length = 8 := by simpa using h₁
  have h₇ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by
    intro h
    use ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i
    have h₈ : ∀ n : ℕ, S n = ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by simp [h₄]
    have h₉ : Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i)) := by
      have h₁₀ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by simp [h₄]
      rw [h₁₀]
      have h₁₁ : ∀ n : ℕ, ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i = ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by simp
      have h₁₂ : Tendsto (fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i) atTop (𝓝 (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i)) := by
        apply tendsto_const_nhds.congr' _
        filter_upwards [eventually_ge_atTop 1] with n hn
        simp_all [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top, Nat.div_eq_of_lt]
        <;> aesop
      exact h₁₂
    exact h₉
  have h₈ : (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
    have h₉ : putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4) := by
      constructor
      · intro h
        aesop
      · intro h
        aesop
    exact h₉
  exact ⟨h₇, h₈⟩
```

import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=

theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have h₁ := hL.2 ⟨0, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₂ := hL.2 ⟨1, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₃ := hL.2 ⟨2, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₄ := hL.2 ⟨3, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₅ := hL.2 ⟨4, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₆ := hL.2 ⟨5, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₇ := hL.2 ⟨6, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  have h₈ := hL.2 ⟨7, by linarith [hL.1]⟩
  simp_all [Fin.sum_univ_succ, Finset.sum_range_succ, Finset.sum_range_one, Finset.sum_singleton,
    Finset.mem_singleton, Finset.mem_Icc, Nat.cast_one, Nat.cast_add, Nat.cast_sub, Nat.cast_mul,
    Nat.cast_succ]
  <;> norm_num
  <;> aesop
```

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=

```lean4
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have h₁ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
    have h₂ := hL.2
    have h₃ := hL.1
    have h₄ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
      -- We need to show that the list L consists of four 1's and four -1's.
      -- This can be done by checking each element in the list.
      have h₅ := h₂ 0
      have h₆ := h₂ 1
      have h₇ := h₂ 2
      have h₈ := h₂ 3
      have h₉ := h₂ 4
      have h₁₀ := h₂ 5
      have h₁₁ := h₂ 6
      have h₁₂ := h₂ 7
      have h₁₃ := h₂ 8
      simp_all (config := {decide := true})
      <;> aesop
    exact h₄
  have h₂ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by
    intro h
    -- Given that there are four +1's and four -1's, the series converges.
    use ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i
    have h₃ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by rw [hS]
    have h₄ : ∀ n : ℕ, S n = ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by simp [h₃]
    have h₅ : Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i)) := by
      rw [show S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i by rw [hS]]
      apply tendsto_nhds_of_metric.mpr
      intro ε εpos
      use 1
      intro n n_ge_one
      simp_all [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top, h₁, Finset.sum_range_succ, Finset.sum_range_one]
      <;> norm_num
      <;> linarith
    exact h₅
  have h₃ : (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
    constructor
    · intro h
      simp_all [h₂]
      <;> aesop
    · intro h
      have h₄ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by apply h₂
      have h₅ : (∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4 := by
        intro h₆
        simp_all [h₂]
        <;> aesop
      simp_all [h₄, h₅]
      <;> aesop
  exact ⟨h₂, h₃⟩
```

theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have h₁ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
    have h₂ := hL.2 0
    have h₃ := hL.2 1
    have h₄ := hL.2 2
    have h₅ := hL.2 3
    have h₆ := hL.2 4
    have h₇ := hL.2 5
    have h₈ := hL.2 6
    have h₉ := hL.2 7
    simp at h₂ h₃ h₄ h₅ h₆ h₇ h₈ h₉
    have h₁₀ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
      cases L <;> simp_all (config := {decide := true}) <;>
        (try contradiction) <;>
        (try aesop)
    exact h₁₀
  have h₂ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by
    intro h
    use ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i
    have h₃ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := by rw [hS]
    have h₄ : Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i)) := by
      simpa [h₃] using tendsto_const_nhds
    simpa [h₃] using h₄
  have h₃ : (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
    have h₄ : putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4) := by
      constructor
      · intro h
        aesop
      · intro h
        aesop
    exact h₄
  exact ⟨by aesop, by aesop⟩
```

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Nat Set MeasureTheory Topology Filter

abbrev putnam_1973_a2_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Consider an infinite series whose $n$th term is given by $\pm \frac{1}{n}$, where the actual values of the $\pm$ signs repeat in blocks of $8$ (so the $\frac{1}{9}$ term has the same sign as the $\frac{1}{1}$ term, and so on). Call such a sequence balanced if each block contains four $+$ and four $-$ signs. Prove that being balanced is a sufficient condition for the sequence to converge. Is being balanced also necessary for the sequence to converge?
-/
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) :=

```lean4
theorem putnam_1973_a2
(L : List ℝ)
(hL : L.length = 8 ∧ ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1)
(pluses : ℕ)
(hpluses : pluses = {i : Fin L.length | L[i] = 1}.ncard)
(S : ℕ → ℝ)
(hS : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8]/i)
: (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) ∧ (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
  have step1 : (pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) := by
    intro h
    have h₁ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
      have h₂ := hL.2
      have h₃ := hL.1
      have h₄ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
        have h₅ : L.length = 8 := hL.1
        have h₆ : ∀ i : Fin L.length, L[i] = 1 ∨ L[i] = -1 := hL.2
        have h₇ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
          have h₈ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
            apply Eq.symm
            apply Eq.symm
            have h₉ := h₆
            have h₁₀ := h₅
            cases L <;> simp_all (config := {decide := true}) <;>
            (try {
              aesop
            }) <;>
            (try {
              simp_all [Fin.forall_fin_succ, Fin.ext_iff] <;> norm_num <;> aesop
            }) <;>
            aesop
          exact h₈
        exact h₇
      exact h₄
    have h₂ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := hS
    have h₃ : ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := by
      use ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i
      have h₄ : S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i := h₂
      rw [h₄]
      have h₅ : ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i = L[1 % 8] / 1 := by
        simp [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top]
        <;> rfl
      have h₆ : L[1 % 8] / 1 = 1 := by
        simp [h₁]
        <;> norm_num
      have h₇ : Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i)) := by
        rw [show S = fun n : ℕ ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, L[i % 8] / i by rw [h₂]]
        have h₈ : ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 1, L[i % 8] / i = 1 := by
          simp_all [h₁, Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top] <;> norm_num
          <;> aesop
        rw [h₈]
        have h₉ : Tendsto (fun n : ℕ => (1 : ℝ)) atTop (𝓝 1) := tendsto_const_nhds
        simpa using h₉
      exact h₇
    exact h₃
  
  have step2 : (putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4)) := by
    have h₃ : putnam_1973_a2_solution ↔ ((∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4) := by
      have h₄ : pluses = 4 → ∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l) := step1
      have h₅ : (∃ l : ℝ, Tendsto S atTop (𝓝 l)) → pluses = 4 := by
        intro h
        have h₆ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
          have h₇ := hL.2
          have h₈ := hL.1
          have h₉ : L = [1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1, -1, -1] := by
            have h₁₀ := h₇
            have h₁₁ := h₈
            cases L <;> simp_all (config := {decide := true}) <;>
            (try { aesop }) <;>
            (try { simp_all [Fin.forall_fin_succ, Fin.ext_iff] <;> norm_num <;> aesop }) <;>
            aesop
          exact h₉
        simp_all [hpluses, hS, h₆, Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top]
        <;> norm_num at * <;> aesop
      tauto
    exact h₃
  
  exact ⟨step1, step2⟩
```
